fields.descriptive_line: Four-poster bed of carved oak, English, 1530-40, said to have come from Crackenthorpe Hall, Westmorland. 95/335
fields.physical_description:
Bedstead of carved oak. On the headboard at the top is a frieze of confronting monsters, supporting an heraldic shield inlaid with the letters 'H. F.' in mastic. 
Below are three panels showing designs of doves partaking of the Tree of Life with ribbons inscribed respectively in burnt Gothic letters: 'DREDE GOD, LOVE GOD, PRAYES GOD'. 
At the base of the headboard, four panels showing designs of flowering trees. Crocketted cornice carved on the sinister side with confronting monsters supporting a blank shield scratched with a merchant's mark and similarly carved in the dexter side. The shield is blank. 
The bedstock is surrounded by friezes showing:
(1) on the sinister side a trail of foliage 
(2) on the dexter side a pattern of diamond compartments containing leaf motives
(3) at the foot, trails of foliage supporting a shield inlaid with mastic with the initials 'J.J'
The short square bedstock posts are carved with foliage on the outer sides. The foot posts are square below and octagonal carved with diamond compartments with leaf motives, towards the top are square shield-faced bosses, that on the sinister side showing the Lamb of God, scratched, and towards the foot, the Sacred Monogram inlaid with mastic. 
Formerly in possession of the family of Machel, Crackentope Hall, Westmorland.
fields.dimensions: Height: 209.6 cm, Length: 215.9 cm, Width: 142.9 cm
fields.bibliography:
<u>50 Masterpieces of Woodwork</u>. Victoria and Albert Museum, London, 1955, no. 15.
This dates the bed to about 1530-40, suggesting that carving is Westmorland may have been more conservative than in metropolitant centres. The photograph shows the bed with a full tester, which the text records was made for the bed when it came to the Museum.  It is noted that the frieze and cornice are later, but makes no mention of other anomalies in the construction of the bed.
fields.history_note: The bed was purchased by that National Aart-Collections Fund (now The Art Fund) for £150 in 1943 from Major J.S. Clift, Cheltenham, who had bought it earlier the same year at the death of Mrs Francis Mary Bellamy, 6 Howlett Street, Cheltenham, who was born a Machel and who received the bed from Crackenthorpe Hall, nr. Appleby, Westmorland, the family home of the Machel's. The history of the family is recorded in E. Bellasis, 'Machel of Crackenthorpe' in the 'Transactions of the Cumberland and Westmorland Antiquarian and Archaeological Society', 1st Series, vol. VIII, 1886, pp. 416-466.
